column4: looking at some comments from Blue on the various bug reports, it looks as if Ubuntu IS changing drive parameters!
well, i don't know if there are cases when laptop_mode is enabled by default, would have to grep through the installer's source to make sure..

according to Blue's comments he just exchanged hdparm with a logging script in a clean install, and it is called with the harmfull hdparm -B 1, so it does not really matter if laptop_mode is enabled or not.
BTW: for me laptop_mode reduces the Load_Cycle to (still to high) 2-5/min, without it's up to 10/min...
i've just grepped my ubuntu systems for calls to hdparm and traced them back .. i'll use a logging script just to be sure..
I am very interested in your results. Unfortunately I only have a system that has been dist-upgraded since hoary, so no clean install...
no clean install to test with
not a single call to hdparm. this is an upgraded system too, though. feisty-beta i think.
interesting. There might still of course be cases where this differs.
do mind answering a few question over this respective system? such as: are acpi, apm activ?
this system here is a perfectly normal desktop - core2duo, acpi enabled, using x86_64
is laptop-mode-tools installes?
yes
but not active I guess?
have you tried suspend to ram and if it's calling hdparm on waking up?
ENABLE_LAPTOP_MODE=false in acpi-support
i don't think str works on this mainboard.. hrm, well don't think i ever tried. let's see..
it actually works, but doesn't invoke hdparm either.
ok, so it's not the case for every system and might only occur in some corner cases. For me personally it's pretty anoying and can unfortunately not be solved with hdparm -B or -S :-(
if you can't fix it with hdparm -B 255 i would assume it's a builtin "feature"
i think it's the fault of my Samsung drive, that does not care what hdparm tells it. So in some way it's a builtin "feature" yes.
at the same time the disc is specified for 600000 cycles and I'm at almost 400000 already, counting rapidly. So if it's builtin in, then it's pretty stupid.
and that's why i think the noise about this issue is a bigger problem for hdd manufacturers than ubuntu :]
it probably should be. But probably it's more sales for them and bad publicity for Ubuntu, as people do not necessarly care about the complex background.
